course_main_structural_unit.address:
Lossi 36
51003 Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.en: The main topics of this course are datafication, AI, (breaking) social norms in digital cultures, dark participation, shaming, affordances, platforms, influencer cultures, gender and networked misogyny, digital intimacies, sex and sexuality online.
description.et: Kursuse põhiteemadeks on andmestumine, tehisintellekt, sotsiaalsed normid digikultuurides ning nende rikkumine, tumedad osaluspraktikad, häbistamine, lubavused, platvormid, sisuloojate kultuurid, sugu ja võrgustunud misogüünia, seks ja seksuaalsus digikultuuris.

objectives.en: The aim of this course is to introduce students to the central theoretical and empirical concepts relating to information society and media studies. We will delve into various digital cultures and some of information society's central interdisciplinary problems and phenomena. In a sense, the student will get a roadmap, which will support them in understanding, analysing and managing behaviors, problems and informational needs relating to the course's topics. While the core of the course is in media and communication studies, it is heavily influenced by semiotics, economics, sociology, political science, information sciences, education, psychology and law.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärgiks on tutvustada tudengitele infoühiskonna ja meediauuringute keskseid teoreetilisi ja empiirilisi kontseptsioone. Süveneme erinevatesse digikultuuridesse ning infoühiskonnaga seonduvatesse interdistsiplinaarsetesse probleemidesse ja nähtustesse. Kursuse käigus saab tudeng teatud mõttes teekaardi, mis aitab tal käsitletavate teemadega seonduvaid käitumispraktikaid, probleeme ja infovajadusi paremini mõista, analüüsida ja juhtida. Kursuse tuum on meedia ja kommunikatsiooni valdkonnas, kuid pisteliselt kohtub ka teemadega, mis on aktuaalsed ka ka semiootikas, majanduses, sotsioloogias, politoloogias, infoteadustes, arvutiteadustes, haridusteadustes, psühholoogias ja juuras.

learning_outcomes.en: After completing this course, the student:
- is familiar with more common theories and everyday concepts of information society, both on the macro and micro level;
learning_outcomes.et: - tunneb Tudeng levinumaid teooriaid ja igapäevakäsitlusi infoühiskonnast nii makro- kui ka mikrotasandil;

learning_outcomes.en: - is familiar with the vocabulary and has the skills to seek further information on concepts in information society and media studies;
learning_outcomes.et: - valdab Tudeng sõnavara ja otsib täiendavat informatsiooni infoühiskonna ning meediauuringutes kasutatavate kontseptsioonide kohta;

learning_outcomes.en: - is able to discuss and critically analyse some of the contemporary issues relating to information society.
learning_outcomes.et: - analüüsib Tudeng kriitiliselt tänast ühiskonda infoühiskonna teooriate valguses.

description.en:
Social Norms Online – 15p, deadline: 16.03.25 at 23.59. Estimated time: 18 hours.
For this task you get to choose between two options.
Option 1 (social norms in a community) – find an online community that has social norms which surprise you and are somehow out of the ordinary. You can’t be a current member of this community – the experience has to be new for you. This community might have surprising ways of doing things or weird rules for behaviour that you do not necessarily understand. Spend some time lurking in this community, see what they post, what’s happening, maybe even try to post something yourself and see what happens. Are there any conflicts happening? What are they generally about? In this lurking process, try to figure out what is the rationale behind the social norms of these communities, why do you think they have developed this way. You should take notes in the lurking process, that will make writing the report easier. Write a short analysis of this community where you introduce the community, give a good overview of what’s happening there. Introduce the social norms that are evident in the group and discuss why do you think these have developed, what function do they serve. Reflect also on the potential conflicts happening in the group – what are they usually about, why do they keep happening? Finally, reflect on your experience as a member of the group (what surprised you, what didn’t, what made you uncomfortable, etc). In the process of this assignment, make sure you’re respectful of other people’s privacy and don’t reveal their identity. Max word count: 600 words.

Option 2 (gender norms) – play a video game for a minimum of 6 hours as someone explicitly from a different gender than yourself. Try to approach this task by examining your biases, stereotypes and attitudes. Don't go full caricature but still, try to embody a masculine/feminine (humor the binaries here please) gamer that is different from your usual self. Post a short video where you tell us a little about this experience: for example, what did you do? How did you perform gender? How is gender usually performed in this game/games? What happened? Did something surprise you? What was in line with your expectations? Would this be a typical experience? If necessary, add others' lived experiences to your experience - interviews. The video should be around 3-6 minutes long.

description.en:
Digital Detox essay 20 p, deadline 27.04.25 at 23.59, estimated time: 24 hours.
Individual assignment. Stop using social media (mainly focusing on the use of social networking sites) for five consecutive days. For real. Keep a diary. You can use your devices for the truly unavoidable but steer clear of Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat, Tumblr, Tinder, even YouTube and blogs, etc. Keep a diary of your "trials and tribulations". The diary is accessible only to you and the lecturers of that course (Õpipäevik tool in Moodle). If you want to go totally off-the-grid, we accept this assignment to be handed in on paper, written by hand. We encourage you to interpret this exercise freely, you do not have to follow the instructions on the dot. One suggested structure you can (but do not have to!!!) follow - for each day (you can make several entries per day) try to give:
A general description of your day and in which are your daily rituals and routines (you had to make adjustments to due to the abstinence of social media)
What functions does social media carry for you? Has something replaced the role of social media?
What were the positive sides of this day? What did you win/gain?
What were the negative aspects of this day? What did you miss?
How did the absence of social media make you feel at different points?
How did this day and this experiment influence your social/informational/private/professional relationships and needs?
…
Max length: 7 pages (formatting: 1,5 spacing, justified, Times New Roman 12 pt).

description.en:
Final video 20p, deadline 27.05.25 at 23.59, estimated time: 25 hours.
In self-selected groups of 2-4 people, put together a well-executed video presentation. Make a max 5-minute YouTube video (or a series of TikToks) about a specific topic that sparked your interest in this course. Read a bit more about the topic and YT/TT genres, teach us some new interesting things with this material. Here's the catch - the video(s) has to make use and follow the structure and storytelling techniques of specific genres of YouTube/TikTok. Make audiovisual content that you would be proud to show outside the class as well. This takes planning and time for recording and editing. The final video should be of good quality (keep audio in mind) and recognizable by genre, so do the background-research (read: watch a looooot of YT videos/TikToks).

grade_preconditions.en: By the end of the course you will be graded (A, B, C, D, E, F). The person from the class who has managed to collect the most points will set a standard for the whole course - their points will be taken as the max needed to get an A.
